body:
Apparently this also happens with the global Desktop Audio source, either on the default setting or with a specific device selected. OBS *reports* that it initialised the device correctly, but doesn't display/capture any audio. Input devices works fine.

`22:16:20.229: WASAPI: Device 'Headphones (Arctis 7 Game)' [48000 Hz] initialized`

Edit: This isn't just a visual issue either, the recording doesn't contain the audio either.

Current running theory is that this bug was introduced in the below PR, which contains 16 commits. I am personally unsure which could have introduced it.

* #5269
Follow-up from my earlier suspicion. This issue was introduced by the specific commit https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/commit/24d8206.

issue.title: win-wasapi: Only enable work queue on Windows 10+

labels.name: Bug Fix
labels.description: Non-breaking change which fixes an issue

milestone.title: OBS Studio 27.2
milestone.description:
Items that we would like to consider for inclusion in OBS Studio v27.2.

NOTE: Items on this list are not promised to be in the listed release, just that we are considering them. This list is subject to change at any time.

repository.name: obs-studio
repository.description: OBS Studio - Free and open source software for live streaming and screen recording

issue.body:
### Description

According to rcdrone and Microsoft's documentation, work queues are properly supported on Windows 8.1 and above. However, since 27.2's release, we've heard reports that while Mic/Aux capture works correctly (verified), Desktop Audio does not (also verified).

This locks the work queue code behind a Windows 10 check. 

I did attach a debugger to a debug build of OBS but none of the `throws` were hit, and I don't understand the code well enough to track down what could be happening.

### Motivation and Context

* Fixes #5967

### How Has This Been Tested?

* Launch OBS on Windows 8.1
* Play audio
* Notice it's captured

### Types of changes

 - Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

### Checklist:

- [x] My code has been run through [clang-format](https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/blob/master/.clang-format).
- [x] I have read the [**contributing** document](https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst).
- [x] My code is not on the master branch.
- [x] The code has been tested.
- [x] All commit messages are properly formatted and commits squashed where appropriate.
- [x] I have included updates to all appropriate documentation.

issue.title: Audio Output not working on Windows Server 2016/OBS 27.2 (WASAPI Work Queue-related)

labels.name: Confirmed
labels.description: This bug report has been confirmed by project members

repository.name: obs-studio
repository.description: OBS Studio - Free and open source software for live streaming and screen recording

issue.body:
### Operating System Info

Other

### Other OS

Windows Server 2016 Datacenter Edition

### OBS Studio Version

27.2.3

### OBS Studio Version (Other)

_No response_

### OBS Studio Log URL

https://obsproject.com/logs/HDv_ArGz4pRbSRuq

### OBS Studio Crash Log URL

_No response_

### Expected Behavior

OBS should capture desktop audio and show the stereo meter (two green bars) moving in the audio mixer.

### Current Behavior

OBS silently fails to capture audio and shows a single mono bar with no activity.

- Attempting to switch audio capture sources changes the monitor to display stereo bars and a brief peak of audio activity (regardless of actual audio) which then disappears.

### Steps to Reproduce

~~1. Add audio output source in a blank scene collection~~
Edit: This was actually tested by simply attempting to record/monitor desktop audio, either via "Default" device or selecting USB audio.

### Anything else we should know?

- I'm 99% sure this is the same issue as https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/issues/5967
- Microphone capture works fine, as in the above mentioned issue.

- WizardCM's fix, https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/pull/5980, looks good, but unfortunately does not apply to Windows Server 2016 because **the version check for Windows 10+ includes WS2016.**

To verify that WASAPI work queue is the issue, I've recompiled OBS Studio from source myself and **manually set rtwq_supported to false**.  **I've verified that this fixes the issue in my build**.  Replacing the rebuilt win-wasapi.dll plugin alone in a precompiled release binary also solves the issue.

I imagine that Windows Server 2016 is an extremely niche environment for OBS so you may have to take my word for it that this is broken.  The desired fix is pretty simple here, the problem is implementing the version check.  I've looked into this a little bit myself but I'm a bit hesitant to submit a PR as a first-time contributor because it didn't seem trivial.

There are a few existing threads out there about this sort of thing which I'm sure you can find yourself.
This particular stackoverflow answer seems to be elucidating, as an example: https://stackoverflow.com/a/61212831

**I can confirm that my "ReleaseId" is 1607 in my registry.**  Here are the relevant other values from HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion:

```
CurrentBuild: 14393
CurrentBuildNumber: 14393
CurrentMajorVersionNumber: 0x0000000a (10)
CurrentMinorVersionNumber: 0x00000000 (0)
CurrentVersion: 6.3
EditionID: ServerDatacenter
InstallationType: Server
ProductName: Windows Server 2016 Datacenter
ReleaseId: 1607
UBR: 0x0000138e (5006)
```

It looks like you're already parsing ReleaseId, but only in crash handlers and not actually keeping it in the win_version_info struct.

Given that Windows Server is relatively obscure as a desktop environment, I'm happy to test a fix and/or provide additional diagnostics if you'd like to direct me.  Feel free to reach out via email or contact me on the OBS discord at DDRKirby(ISQ)#2445
